qas.question: What concept's use has declined significantly in the U.S. during the 20th century?
The majority of what group in the U.S. has rejected the concept of biological races?
What textbooks introducing anthropology have rejected race as a valid concept since 1932?
How many books out of 33, from 1975 to 1984, rejected race?
What percentage of articles in 1996 employed a bio-race paradigm?

context: The concept of <a0_0>biological race<a0_0/> has declined significantly in frequency of use in physical anthropology in the United States during the 20th century. A majority of <a1_0>physical anthropologists<a1_0/> in the United States have rejected the concept of biological races. Since 1932, an increasing number of <a2_0>college<a2_0/> textbooks introducing physical anthropology have rejected race as a valid concept: from 1932 to 1976, only seven out of thirty-two rejected race; from 1975 to 1984, <a3_0>thirteen<a3_0/> out of thirty-three rejected race; from 1985 to 1993, thirteen out of nineteen rejected race. According to one academic journal entry, where 78 percent of the articles in the 1931 Journal of Physical Anthropology employed these or nearly synonymous terms reflecting a bio-race paradigm, only 36 percent did so in 1965, and just <a4_0>28 percent<a4_0/> did in 1996.
